sections.title: Foreword
sections.summary: Darrell Guder provides a foreword that situates The Permanent Revolution within the broader missional church conversation. He highlights the book's focus on recovering apostolic ministry as essential for missional ecclesiology, noting how the Western church has historically reduced the fivefold ministry to just pastoral and teaching functions. Guder emphasizes the critical need for apostolic ministry to ensure the church remains centered on its missional calling.

sections.title: Introduction
sections.summary: The introduction addresses the crisis of infertility in the Western church, arguing that decline stems from missional doubt and the failure to align with God's original design. It introduces the concept of 'black swan events' and paradigm shifts, arguing that the church must rediscover its identity as an apostolic movement rather than a static institution. The chapter establishes the book's central thesis: that recovering Ephesians 4:11 ministry, especially the apostolic function, is essential for the church to become the 'permanent revolution' it was designed to be.

sections.title: Preface: A Briefing for the Journey
sections.summary: The preface explains the authors' motivations for writing this comprehensive work on Ephesians 4 and apostolic ministry. It addresses the poverty of theological reflection on these topics and outlines the book's interdisciplinary approach, drawing from theology, organizational theory, and social sciences. The authors acknowledge they are challenging inherited paradigms and ask readers to approach the material with open minds, willing to reconsider long-held assumptions about ministry and leadership.

sections.title: Activating the Theo-Genetic Codes of APEST Ministry
sections.summary: This foundational chapter establishes Ephesians 4:1-16 as the constitutional document for church ministry, arguing that APEST (Apostle, Prophet, Evangelist, Shepherd, Teacher) represents the theo-genetic codes of the church. It explores how the church has been engaged in a Sisyphean struggle by ignoring these foundational ministries, particularly the exile of APE (Apostle, Prophet, Evangelist) functions. The chapter examines the text's three movements (unity, diversity, maturity) and argues that the fivefold ministry is given to all believers, not just leaders, representing the ministry of Christ expressed through his body.

sections.title: An Elegant Solution
sections.summary: This chapter provides detailed definitions and characteristics of each APEST ministry type, framing them as distinct forms of intelligence (AQ, PQ, EQ, SQ, TQ). It explores prophetic intelligence as guardians of covenant faithfulness, evangelistic intelligence as recruiters to the cause, shepherd intelligence focused on empathic community, and teacher intelligence mediating wisdom. The chapter emphasizes how each ministry brings unique perspectives to the gospel and how their combination creates a synergistic corporate intelligence that enables the church to fulfill its missional calling.

sections.title: Better Together
sections.summary: This chapter explores the synergistic relationships within APEST, particularly the foundational partnership between apostles and prophets, and the complementary roles of apostles and evangelists. It examines how prophets provide intelligence to guide apostolic decision-making, ensuring faithfulness to God's intent. The chapter distinguishes between apostolic and evangelistic ministries, showing how apostles extend Christianity through multiplication while evangelists recruit through addition. It also explores spatial profiles of each ministry type and the pioneer-settler dynamic essential for missional movement.

sections.title: Missional Ministry for a Missional Church
sections.summary: This comprehensive chapter explores how to integrate APEST into the fabric of the church through the dynamics of differentiation and integration. It examines how to recognize and legitimize unique APEST vocations while creating meaningful interaction among them. The chapter addresses the clergy-laity dichotomy and argues for the ministry of all believers, showing how APEST should function at every level from discipleship to leadership development. It provides practical frameworks for activating fivefold ministry throughout the church system.

sections.title: Mapping the Contours of Apostolic Ministry
sections.summary: This chapter provides foundational definitions of apostolic ministry, exploring Paul's metaphors (planter, architect, foundation layer, father, ambassador) and establishing the apostolic as custodian of the gospel's DNA. It outlines four core functions: seeding the DNA through pioneering, guarding the DNA against mutation, networking the movement, and creating environments for other ministries to flourish. The chapter distinguishes between 'little a' and 'big A' apostles while maintaining continuity with biblical precedents, and examines the consequences of excluding apostolic ministry from the church.

sections.title: Living from the Center: Apostolic Ministry and the Renewal of Christianity
sections.summary: This chapter explores the distinction between Pauline and Petrine models of apostolic ministry. Pauline apostles are cross-cultural pioneers who extend Christianity to unreached peoples, while Petrine apostles focus on reframing and revitalizing existing churches. The chapter examines how both models share core functions but exhibit unique strengths, and how they work together to create comprehensive apostolic impact. It categorizes apostolic types as pioneers, miners, networkers, and mobilizers, showing how different APEST profiles influence apostolic expression.

sections.title: The Enterprise of Movement and the Movement of Enterprise
sections.summary: This chapter examines how apostolic ministry facilitates ongoing renewal in the church through the dialectic between center and borderlands. It explores organizational life cycles and how different leadership types are needed at various stages. The chapter emphasizes Petrine apostolic ministry's role in refounding and revitalizing established communities, helping them rediscover their original purpose. It discusses the 'flywheel effect' of long-term apostolic work and how renewal emerges through engagement at the organizational edges, where new problems invite innovative solutions.

sections.title: Come Back Peter, Come Back Paul
sections.summary: This chapter explores apostolic entrepreneurship as the archetypal pioneering form of leadership. It examines the characteristics of pioneers, including their ability to invent the future while dealing with the past, willingness to break with tradition, capacity for multiple roles, and high tolerance for risk. The chapter outlines seven elements of entrepreneurial people and categorizes four types of organizational entrepreneurship (nominal, sporadic, franchised, dynamic). It emphasizes the need to balance exploration and exploitation, and discusses the three essential components for start-up success: the right idea, the right people, and the right resources.

sections.title: The Spirit of Innovation
sections.summary: This chapter focuses on innovation as a key component of apostolic leadership, arguing that innovation arises from bringing different 'idea spaces' together at intersections. It explores how apostolic people, through their translocal and cross-cultural work, naturally create conditions for innovation. The chapter examines living with ambiguity, thinking like beginners rather than experts, embracing failure, and the importance of improvisation. It distinguishes between missionary innovation (contextualizing the gospel in new cultures) and missional innovation (renewing established churches), showing how both are essential for apostolic ministry.

sections.title: Movements R Us
sections.summary: This chapter argues that movements are the quintessentially apostolic form of the church, exploring how to think and act like a movement. It examines the characteristics of apostolic movements: they thrive in an atmosphere of belief, exhibit network structures, spread like viruses, and are reproducing and reproducible. The chapter uses the starfish and spider metaphor to illustrate decentralized organization, showing how movements operate as fractal networks where every part contains the potential of the whole. It emphasizes planting movements rather than churches, and planting the gospel rather than imposing ecclesial forms.

sections.title: Apostolic Architecture
sections.summary: This chapter explores how to structure apostolic movements, examining the relationship between modalities (local churches) and sodalities (task-oriented mission structures). It argues that both forms are needed and must work together for effective movement. The chapter critiques the outsourcing of learning to institutions and professionals, calling for theological reflection to return to local ecclesia. It examines how apostolic bands function, using Paul's missionary team as a model, and shows how sodalic structures can support and multiply modalic expressions while maintaining mutuality and interdependence.

sections.title: Conclusion: The Mission Has a Church
sections.summary: The conclusion emphasizes that the mission has a church, not the other way around, grounding Christian mission in the being and purposes of God. It calls for rediscovering the primal purpose of the church through radical traditionalismâ€”reinterpreting founding charisms for contemporary expression. The chapter summarizes how apostolic ministry mediates the vital dialectic of renewal, extending Christianity into new situations while safeguarding foundational truths. It ends with a call to receive apostolic ministry as a gift of grace that enables the permanent revolution.

sections.title: Afterword by Mike Breen
sections.summary: Mike Breen shares his personal journey of discovering his apostolic calling, recounting how he struggled for years in traditional pastoral roles before fully embracing his apostolic identity. He describes how this led to the creation of Missional Communities and a movement that transformed his church. Breen emphasizes the urgency of restoring the apostolic voice in the Western church, noting declining attendance rates. He sees this book as a significant step in legitimizing apostolic ministry by developing vocational language, practices, and paradigms that have been lacking for too long.

sections.title: Notes
sections.summary: This extensive appendix provides a detailed historical and theological examination of why apostles, prophets, and evangelists were exiled from the church's ministry mix. It explores the process of routinization of charisma, the development of institutional structures, and how the church shifted from movemental to institutional forms. The appendix examines the role of writings, doctrine, and organizational development in this transition, and argues for the restoration of apostolic ministry as foundational to authentic church life and mission.

sections.title: Index
sections.summary: This section contains the book's index, providing references to key topics, names, and concepts throughout the text. It serves as a navigational tool for readers seeking to locate specific discussions of APEST ministries, apostolic functions, organizational principles, and related theological and missiological themes.

sections.title: The Authors
sections.summary: This brief section provides information about the authors, Alan Hirsch and Tim Catchim, including their backgrounds, ministry experience, and contributions to the missional church movement.
